abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Social Protection
            Adjustment Loan (SPAL) Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as highly likely, institutional development
            impact as substantial, bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The lessons learned
            from the project include: The accomplishment of the SPAL
            objectives required long government commitment to the
            reform. Sufficient management and implementation capacity
            needed to be in place within the government and especially
            within the implementing agency. Some flexibility of the
            conditionalities and benchmarks is needed to reflect the
            changing external conditions, the balance-of-payments and
            fiscal situation, and as a result of re-thinking of reform
            priorities and sequencing of reforms. In the second tranche
            conditionality, the government and the Bank were bound to
            precise conditions which may have needed refining as time
            passed. Technical assistance and other donor financial
            support helped in some of the design and implementation work
            of the SPAL. Timely parallel operations prevented
            overloading the SPAL and optimized the linkages among the
            operations, but required coordination. Given the
            complementary nature of the content of the SPAL and the
            International Monetary Fundx program, coordination between
            the Bank and the Fund was essential. The SPAL required on
            the ground support due to the need for constant
            communication between the government and the Bank in dealing
            with implementation issues.
